awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Aqueous Lithium and Zinc Ion Batteries for Stationary Energy Storage Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the commercialization of an aqueous lithium and zinc ion battery that is a replacement for lead-acid and lithium-ion batteries in stationary energy storage applications.  This battery has a nonflammable, environmentally-friendly, water-based electrolyte and does not utilize cobalt or nickel, reducing reliance on critical materials and helping to diversify battery material supply chains.  The battery chemistry combines the high safety and low cost associated with zinc-based batteries with the long life of lithium-ion batteries.  This aqueous battery may help to advance the adoption of beneficial energy technologies such as intermittent renewables and electric vehicles.  The battery utilizes zinc that can be sourced domestically and does not introduce a dependency on foreign sources, promoting both national security and the creation of US-based jobs.  The battery is also fully recyclable using existing methods.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to develop the aqueous lithium and zinc ion battery technology by focusing on optimization of individual battery components to improve cycle life and power as well as scale up from pouch cells to larger-format prismatic cells.  The research will include refining the intercalation electrode design to increase capacity retention during long life cycling, developing the zinc electrode design to suppress zinc dendrite growth, improving separator functionality to maintain high-rate capabilities and increase cycle life, and developing an electrolyte designed to stabilize zinc while also allowing for faster reactivity with the zinc and lithium ions.  Larger format cells with optimized components will be built and tested to evaluate scaled real-world performance metrics compared to Lead-acid and lithium-ion batteries traditionally used in stationary energy storage applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
AEsir Technologies Inc. has recently completed a Phase II NSF SBIR cooperative agreement that led to the development of a revolutionary Lithium-Zinc (Li-Zn) battery for stationary energy storage applications.  The Li-Zn chemistry combines a Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) cathode with a high energy density, inexpensive, and nontoxic zinc anode, in a water-based electrolyte that contains both lithium and zinc ions.   The battery is cobalt and nickel free and utilizes a higher conductivity and non-flammable electrolyte, which makes this a safe and inexpensive alternative to traditional Lithium-Ion batteries and provides a superior alternative to Lead-Acid. AEsir Technologies has made tremendous progress with their novel Li-Zn battery chemistry since receiving the NSF Phase I SBIR funding. This progress was made through the optimization of the cathode, electrolyte, separator system, cycling parameters, and battery format.  Due to this optimization, the chemistry now projects to have very long cycle life (> 2000 deep discharge cycles), with a cost projected at < 100$/kWh. The demonstrated long life, along with the projected low cost will culminate in a levelized cost of energy of approximately $0.05/kWh. The Li-Zn chemistry uses low-cost water-based manufacturing methods that do not require temperature/humidity control, solvent capture, or advanced safety measures.  The batteries also do not require any formation, meaning that once the cell is filled with electrolyte, it can be shipped directly to the customer.  Manufacturing costs will be very low due to the low-cost materials, simple electrode fabrication, and the elimination of formation time and equipment.

A Li-Zn pouch cell was chosen as the testing vehicle for the larger prototype cells due to the ease of manufacturing and fit with the lower voltage, non-gassing LFP cells. This is also a desired prototype style for potential customer's bench top tests because the prismatic design can be easily scaled to the specifications of the various customers. Prototype 500-1000 mAh pouch cells were cycled at a range of discharge rates after 30 deep discharge cycles to ensure steady cell performance. The Li-Zn chemistry can supply an acceptable amount of energy at discharge rates of 2C to C/20, or a 30 minute to 20-hour discharge time.  While 2C and 1C rates provided a discharge capacity of 80% and 88% utilization, respectively, the chemistry projects as a better fit for C/3 to C/20 applications. The prototype pouch cell performance matches the requirements of the targeted stationary energy storage application and initial data is still being generated for the larger format Li-Zn pouch cells.  Once data is generated and the large pouch cells are performing to expectations, previous and new customers will be reengaged/engaged.  While short/medium duration stationary energy storage was targeted initially, long duration energy storage could be a superior fit, due to the projected levelized cost of energy.


Last Modified: 07/25/2024
Modified by: Adam Weisenstein
